newsitem.title: USA: White House closely monitoring tobacco talks.
newsitem.headline: White House closely monitoring tobacco talks.

text.p: The White House is in almost daily contact with negotiators in the tobacco settlement talks, providing them with President Clinton's views on various proposals, a spokesman said Monday.
"They're indicating publicly that they are into critical stages of their talks and they routinely come by," White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry said.
When asked to describe the role of the White House in the talks, McCurry said: "Still the same. Keeping an eye on it. ... We've given them our tentative reactions to elements of their discussions."
The negotiators have been meeting with Bruce Lindsey, a senior adviser to Clinton. "They talk almost every day," McCurry said.

A total of 37 states are suing cigarette makers to recover Medicaid money spent on treating smoking-related illnesses. The industry wants protection from legal damages but the attorneys general are reluctant to give tobacco companies the immunity from lawsuits they seek.
State officials and tobacco representatives are scheduled to resume talks Monday in Washington.
